video:video.video:description: Michael Howard, Microsoft's top security official, notes that many college graduates need to get remedial security training.

video:video.video:title: Michael Howard - What if we had an unattackable system?
video:video.video:description: What if Michael Howard's job became obsolete? After all, he's the top security official at Microsoft. What would the bad guys do if the system itself became unattackable?

video:video.video:title: Michael Howard - There are people out there that really want to get you
video:video.video:description: Michael Howard, Microsoft's top security official, talks about the risks that exist when you turn on your computer.

video:video.video:title: Eric Lippert - Have you noticed a performance hit in .NET?
video:video.video:description: Eric Lippert takes on the belief that .NET code doesn't perform as well as code written with other methodologies.

video:video.video:title: Eric Lippert - Isn't .NET cool because you don't need to know a lot about how the underlying system
video:video.video:description: Eric Lippert, Microsoft's &quot;scripting guy,&quot; opines on what makes .NET better than, say, old-style Visual C&#43;&#43;.

video:video.video:title: Eric Lippert - What do you think of managed code?
video:video.video:description: Hear Eric Lippert, software design engineer here at Microsoft (we know him as the &quot;scripting guy&quot; because he wrote VBScript and JScript technologies) talk about .NET code.

video:video.video:title: Levy and Griver - What didn't make it in?
video:video.video:description: Jeremy Mazner asks, &quot;What are things that couldn't make it into the product and how did you decide to put it off until next version?&quot;

video:video.video:title: Levy and Griver - Why not complete transparency?
video:video.video:description: Robert Scoble asks,&quot;Why doesn't Microsoft have complete transparency on developer tools?&quot;

video:video.video:title: The 9 Guys - Who We Are
video:video.video:description: Welcome to Channel 9. We are five guys at Microsoft who want a new level of communication between Microsoft and developers. We believe that we will all benefit from a little dialogue these days.&#8230;
